body.p:
It is a long time since I had
the pleasure of hearing from you. Your time
is, I suppose, as usual, pretty well occupied
with your numerous public and private duties,
and as, in addition, you have to chaperone
your nieces, your silence is not surprising. There
is nothing new to communicate respecting
religious matters. The question whether the
Representatives and minister combined are to
decide on the admissibility or not of the required
changes and modifications in public worship, or
whether the minister alone, has not yet been
decided by the Government. The affair is
therefore in status-quo. Meanwhile the small
minority identified with the origination of the
measure, commonly called Mr. Clorio's? clique, keeps
away from the Synagogue, tho', occasionally, its

members are seen in their places. Their chief and I
are not on intimate terms however. I have done,
according to the admission of his own friends, all
that a man and a minister of religion can do, to
reconcile past differences, not of my creating, but
as he is an impracticable man, I have now come
to the inflexible resolution of refusing all further
overtures, and to avoid all risk of prospective
disputes, certain of occurring if we are on speaking
terms, I shall say “Hebrew. Our public
services, particularly on Sabbath mornings, continue
to be well-attended, and Quietness reigns in the
Congregation.

The news of our late lamented friend
Mrs. Ostermans' death gave Mrs. N. and
me a great shock. She was all you
described her. What a melancholy termination
of a noble life. We loved her as a dear sister,
and the time we lived in her house ?,
and she another sister in ours at W/O, were some of
our happiest days on earth. We often recur to
those times with that sadness and regret inseparable

from the thought that they are passed and gone
to return no more. Be good enough to send
me the address of Mrs O's sister Hannah. The
Pollack's will be able to tell you, but I know not
where they live in Pa. How goes on your plan
for a college in your city! I observe that the
situations in the southern congregations are not
yet filled. There must ever be a difficulty in
the way of getting proper men until the college
be established. With the change of the season, to
the great heat felt in this place from May till now,
my liver begins to trouble me. If the complaint
should become as troublesome as it was in 64, I
most certainly will have to take a trip to the states
for a month or two. My good old assistant,
Chazan Maduro, is, I fear, almost past duty. He
is now 68 years old, and a long neglected hernia
is making sad havoc with his constitution. He has
scarcely done any duty the last 5 months. The whole
falls on me. I do not mind the labor for the sake
of the old gentleman, who, if super ? and
pensioner, will lose perhaps more than half his salary,

But I also begin to feel after 32 years residence,
almost, in place-like St. Thomas, Jamaica, and
New Orleans, a want of former rigor and strength.
I have not the energy of former days, at a time
when I require it more than ever to accomplish
a certain object I have long had in view. We manage
to have service every night of the Hebrew, the same as last
year, and 4 services from Friday evening to sabbath
evening. So we are not so bad after all. I coincide
entirely with your arguments against the new views
of Geiger. But the agitation of such questions keeps
alive Jewish attention to the mosaic Religion, and
prevents that apathy and indifference more destructive
to its progress than erroneous theories.

Plenty of opportunities offer themselves monthly
for writing me a few lines. The Brazilian, Venezuelean, and ? steamers bring mails from the states
every month. Mrs. Nathan, her mother, and David join with me in best wishes. Hoping
this will find you in health, and with remembrances
to old inquiring friends, I am, Yours sincerely
